Most of what is on sale is poor quality Chinese produce. Watch your personal belongings in the narrow alleyways and be sure to take a very tough line in bartering in the unlikely event that you see something worth buying.

title: Leuk en rustig
text: Als je in het toeristische gebied verblijft, is een uitstapje naar Banjul heerlijk. Je kunt het "authentieke" Gambia zien en hier laten de mensen je wel meer met rust. Zo af en toe word je wel aangesproken maar erg storend is het hier niet.

title: markt
text: Leuk om te zien hoe de lokale bevolking hun boodschappen doen,maar de markt in Serrakunda is veel groter en ook heel wat drukker...

title: Banjul Market
text:
Bustling and colourful ,friendly and interesting ,but the stallholders will do Anything to make a sale,and will chat for ages.
We went with a guide and were surprised how many aunts sisters and cousins he had running stalls . When we joked about it he said 'we Gambians are ALL family at heart '

title: drukke lokale markt
text:
leuke lokale markt waar veel dingen te koop zijn
het beste kan je hier met een gids heen gaan,
het is er erg druk en iedereen wil wat aan je verkopen.

title: THE REAL GAMBIA
text: Banjul market is a bustling and noisy place which some tourists are not really prepared for as they approach the experience with their own country's mindset.  If people want to see the country as it is, an open mind is needed.  Here is the real Gambia and an active one where people are putting a lot of effort into earning a living.  Gambians are hard working people.  There is no state benefits system such as that in the UK, so the people in Gambia are very resourceful and productive.  The tourists really need to support their enterprise.  Comparing it to shopping experiences in the tourists' home country is unfair and unrealistic.  Tourists know the price of goods in their home country but many are not willing to pay the price when they go there and even expect to under-pay.  They see the local traders as "husslers" though they are just trying to make a living and they put a lot of efffort into it.  I would encourage tourists to support local industry, but also to do as they do at home - shop around!  Get friendly with a local person who knows where the bargains are.  Gambian ladies are always good to know and helpful, telling people where to find the best price for something they want to buy.  Banjul market is good, but also try Senegambia Craft Market on the Bertil Harding Highway.

title: Interessant, aber nichts für empfindliche Europäer...
text: Ursprünglich hatten wir vor den Royal Albert Markt auf eigenen Faust zu erkunden - waren dann aber glücklicherweise mit unserem Taxifahrer unterwegs. Er hat uns herum und auch wieder heraus geführt. Die Die Hitze und der intensive Fischgeruch in den schmalen, z.T. überdachten Gängen sind nichts für zart besaitete Gemüter. Wer einen Blick ins Schlachthaus geworfen hat, freut sich wieder auf die dicke mürrische Verkäuferin an der heimischen Fleischtheke...

title: An experience
text: Very noisy and at times smelly.  Bustling and active.  Every thing you need is there somewhere!  Well worth a vist.

title: Viele Stände, viele Souvenirs
text:
Der Market scheint vor allem für Touristen zu sein, es gibt unendlich viele Souvenirstände mit den immer gleichen Sachen. Allerdings kann man zusehen wie sie gemacht werden, alles Handarbeit also. Die Gassen sind sehr eng zwischen den Ständen, was dort Durchkommen erschwert.
Alles in allem mit dem anschließendem Bootshafen das Interessanteste in Banjul.

title: its an experience
text: There has been a lot of work done to stop this being such a nightmare for tourists from what I understand, we had our taxi driver with us but did not feel in the least bit intimidated. If it were like shopping in Asda......there would be no point!! relax and enjoy....

title: wouldnt go again
text: for some people it may be a great experience but personally i felt like it wasn't something they wanted us to see. ive been to many locals markets while travelling a few years ago, but i dont think the locals want you there so it just makes it uncomfortable for both parties. my suggestion just dont bother going...or just drive past it.

title: well worth a visit
text:
a trip to banjul market is an eye opener if you have never visited an African market before.
you can buy almost anyting you want , but remember to haggle.also take a guide with you or you may be a long time finding your way out

title: As hectic as ever
text: If you've been here before and feel confident about bartering, there really is no need to have the taxi driver come with you. However, if it's your first time you may feel less intimidated if you have a little 'help.'

title: market
text: Al ways go to the market take local person with you this way you don;t get overcharged and they are very helpfull at bartering for taxi ect

title: Artwork
text: I bought some great artwork and the vendors were a lot more layed back than those in other areas. I found lots of examples of unique pieces of canvasses and the locals were happy to make alterartions to some of the leather goods I purchased. I would say its a nice place to pass through rather than spend a extended period.

title: Very upsetting
text: Very dirty and hot, open stalls with blood dripping meat flung over make shift stalls, covered in  hunfreds of flies, second hand clothes stalls and ladies selling fish and veg again everything covered in flies,not for the fainthearted

title: a must see market
text: this is a very eye opening place and certainly a busy one. i didnt enjoy the fish and meat part of the market because of the smell and to many flys

title: Good place to walk around and get a good bargain.
text: Banjul Market is mainly a craft market with loads of wooden items, paintings, fabrics and similar products. I would recommend going with a guide or a local taxi driver because they can help you barter for items and lead you to the right section if you are looking for a particular item. Banjul market is better than Serekunda if you are looking for gifts however if you want fabric I would recommend going to Serekunda instead because you tend to get better deals on fabrics in Serekunda.

title: a rabbit warren
text: It was quite dark inside like a rabbit warren, but the stall holders were very helpful. If they didnt have what you wanted, they knew someone who did! Worth a visit just for the experience.

title: lots to see
text: crafts you can do or watch tie and dye being done and then have a  chance to purchase any of the goods. wood crafts are excellent and an art in there selves.

title: Well Worth a Visit
text:
We used a Green tourist taxi and went on our own as opposed to going via organised tour guide. We like to do our thing in our own time.

The taxi cost 700 dalassi £14, the driver stayed with us all the time and walked us around the market. Which was great because a.) he knew his way around so we did not get lost & b.) he made sure that we did not get hassled, he also explained to us the way the market runs and explained what the produce was that was on sale.
 He then walked us along the beach to the port and back via the fishing village.

A big eye opener on how they live and just how poor they really are.

title: Great place to make friends
text:
The market traders are great people to get to know. I take their photographs whenever I go there but only after asking permission.
The vital part is to give them copies of the photos on your return.
There are some very beautiful people there.
A modelling agency could fill their books.
Watch out for the wheelbarrows!

title: Local market. Must see it.
text:
I good market to start with. There is a bigger one in Serrakunda. You will need a guide that will help you arround on both places.
We recomand that you take a guide and a driver. Then you and the gudie can focus on the trip. No problem with parking etc.
With some tour companies you will get this city tour for free if you book two full day tours.
We can recomand 4*4 south gambia and the safari in senegal.
We used www.bushwhackertours.com with an exellante guide called JJ. We went on four tripps with him. He was very good at adjusting the trip after ours needs.
Well edjucated in history and local coustums.

title: een ander leuk tussendoortje
text: niet slecht maar geef ons maar de serrekunda market.Er is wel iets te zien maar neem een taxi en ga eens naar Bakau fish market of Tanji(zeker te bezoeken

title: nothing great
text: it is nothing great - typcial west african market. but if you have not been to any before, then it is worth a visit. But bargain hard :)

title: Fish section - if you have a strong stomach
text: Exciting place with so  many things to see. The fish section however was a challenge. As there is no cooling, fish are covered with flies and the smell is very very intense.

title: Market
text: The market was extremely clean considering how many stalls there were. It's a must. Lovely people, but you can't buy from them all!

title: Must do
text:
This is a not-to-be-missed experience, the colours, the smells and of course, the people.
Go with a guide.

title: busy busy
text: lots of things to see here, mostly local hand made goods, shopkeepers were nice and chatty, not too much hassle but bartering part of the fun, worth a visit

title: Very local non-touristy
text: Absalutely huge.  We did not stay long as didn't really want to buy. It is packed, smelly and very local. However it is an experience to maybe try!!!

title: Good
text: A lovely little market, but you get hassled ALOT!! Be prepared to have people coming at you from all different directions trying to sell you their goods!!

title: Che posto...
text: Mercato fantastico, quelli che si lamentano di fango e puzza vadano nei grandi centri commerciali...  trovi tutto cio' che riguarda vestiario e tant'altro... Consigliat andare con qualcuno del posto.... Piu' che altro per contrattare meglio... Sai com'e'....:-)

title: Colourful and and Busy
text:
Very busy and colourful, and very smelly (not for the faint hearted)
The craft part at the back of the market is full of stalls selling local crafts but haggle the prices are high.

title: 3 Main Markets at Banjul Market
text:
Fish Market
Art & Crafts Market
Fruit & Veg Market

All reasonably close to each other and worth asking for local prices before entering any of the markets for a fair price.

title: a busy bustling local market full of colour
text: Banjul Market is a large busy,very hot market,where you really need a guide to take you round,to avoid getting too much attention,and to help with bartering and to find your way round.Theres a lot of local colour,some of the fish/meat stalls can be a bit aromotic but this all adds to the excitement of being in an African market,thats more for locals rather than a tourist trap.This is a great stop off if you are visiting Banjul for a taste of local life with friendly smiling stall holders all trying to sell their goods to you.

title: Adventurous
text:
The market in Banjul is worth a trip, just driving thrue Banjul will give you an insight on what an African City means.
Lots of things to see and buy in the market.
It's a real Gambian market, not a tourist trap.

title: Never travel to Banjul, Gambia
text: Extremely dirty muddy place and on top of it  - it is dangerous due to no police or other control. Never eat here and drink only bottled water.

title: Worth visiting
text: Good and cheap gifts.  Can barter with the locals, to get the best price. Well worth visiting the markets.

title: Beautifull market but not if you're alone!
text: Banjul has a beautifull craftmarket where you can buy lots of beautifull craft, such as, batik, woodcarvings, paintings and others. Unfortunatly we where the only ones at the market beacause it was still low season. Everybody is convincing you that they got the nicest shop. Be carefull cause the guides may close a deal with the salesmen and you pay a to high price.

title: Geweldige markt
text: Niet te vergelijken met onze markten. Heel veel mensen veel dieren het is er vies en als je alleen bent zou je zo maar eens kunnen verdwalen.

title: A must experience
text:
Yes it might be overwhelming or even unpleasant at times but to not visit the Albert Market in Banjul would be missing out on the essence of what this place is about. It is a fantastic assault on the sences, best take a local with you and get him to keep you out of the tourist section, no hassel from sellers then as they know you wont want what they sell! 
Dont miss the fish and meat sections.........
Carefull who you point your camera at though, the attention is not always welcome.

title: Weinig diversiteit
text: Als je souvenirs wil, dan kun je die hier halen. Neem wel een gids mee die voor je onderhandelt. Ze hebben houtsnijwerk, schilderijen en batikstoffen.

title: Busy Busy Busy
text: A busy market full of noise and colour, watch out for pick pockets !!!!..... better to take a local tourist guide with you........... you have to barter for everything be prepared to get hassled to buy  but all part of the experience, it can get very hot in the center of Banjul make sure you take water with you

title: Horrible!
text: Very dirty and smelly market...not sure of the exact reason it is included as a place to visit! It was probably for people to shop but believe me, it wasnt worth the stress at all.

title: Leuke toeristenmarkt voor de souvenirs
text: Mocht je op zoek zijn naar leuke souvenirs dan kun je die hier vinden. Elk winkeltje heeft wel hetzelfde maar hierdoor kun je wel afdingen...als je durft!

title: Colour and vibrant
text:
Went round the market looking for fabric.
The market is full of colour and real Banjul life, when going around the market you have some attention. However prepare to be hassled in the craft market, however it is all good fun. If you do not like meat or fish smells avoid this area

title: Nothing special really
text:
We booked a taxi driver for the day & he brought us here to look around. My mom wanted to look at designer bags (which are fake here) but he brought us to the more local-market and we felt kind of uncomfortable in those narrow alleyways between stands and everyone looked at us. It smelled bad, too. He brought us to a stand with leather bags which were nice but I don't like to bargain and to be fair, I don't want a bag in the shape of a voodoo doll when I get back to Holland. So we asked our guide to bring us back to the main street. He didn't know what we meant with designer bags en seemed a bit lost so after two shops (who were nice and airconditioned) we asked to go. 
Prior to this we bought some fabric at a stand where our guide bargained for us so we could buy the nice fabric to be tailored into dresses. We paid 800 dalasi for 2 pieces. We had it tailored at the Senegambia hotel by Aida for 1350 (not each, but in total).

title: Great place but full on!
text:
i loved visiting the markets, they are buzzing so it can be full on at times as everyone tries to sell you things as you are a tourist.  Don't get caught up in this, only pick up things if you are interested otherwise you may find yourself stuck there for a lot longer than you want to be!  make sure you take water as it gets hot walking around the markets during the day with the heat.  

If you aren't one for seeing animals (i.e. butchers/fishmongers) be warned you will come across stalls like this with everything out on the floor.... it's the way it is done so cover your nose and close your mouth to avoid the strong smells.  Just remember you are seeing the reality which is definately in technicolour in this place - Fab!

title: Bumster nightmare
text: Aggressively hassled and harassed by bumsters, security guards and stall holders.  Will never return.

title: WHAT AN EXPERIENCE
text: The local just dont let you get on with just browsing

title: Local flavours - good and bad!
text:
Visiting the local market/souk or whatever they are called are always a must when traveling to exotic places - and the Banjul market as such resembles what you will find across Africa. It is hectic, noisy, smelly - and so interesting!

Obviously you have to fight off the beggars once in a while, but if you go with a determined mind they are not too hard to get rid off. It is not easy to know when you can take a picture and when not - and your eyes see so many things, your camera wishes to bring back home. But mostly you will have to keep those memories in your head to not risk offending the locals. 

If however you shop non-tourist items you will not have to bargain, and the experience will be so much nicer. I brought back plastic dishes, mugs etc. at the ridiculous price of 30-40 euro cents each, and the seller did everything to make me happy finding the exact color and pattern I wanted!

It is however recommended to bring your taxi driver, as you will otherwise find yourselves with a lot of people talking to you only to later claim you own them money for guidance!

title: AN EXPERIENCE
text:
a  busy market full of noise and colour, watch your pockets.
this is where you have to barter for everything,people great, goods great.

title: dirty crowded
text: oh my  god what can you  say  dirty  cheap tatt and  very pressured to buy. Its  almost threatening

title: Worth a visit
text: You do get hassled alot but worth a visit. You can get a local yellow and green taxi there and there are plenty of taxi available to get back to your hotel

title: Disgusting and pushy
text: The market is just plain disgusting. Lots of rotten fish and vegetables being sold, the stench is unbearable. The craftmarket is full of pushy people, just dragging you by your arm into their stores. They say they're offended if you don't look around, but their even worse when you do. We just left.

title: Albert  fish n fly market!?!
text: Although the craft market offers some unusual locally made goods,the rest of the market on the whole,is there to serve the locals with "fresh" local produce.It can be very "aromatic" and hot,very busy with locals "on their missions",but on the outskirts are some very good trading outlets,(all round the city of Banjul),so best to wander or explore and avoid the market early morning.Once ventured never forgotten folks?

title: Lo único interesante de Banjul
text: Banjul es una ciudad inhóspita y dura. No por falta de seguridad, ningún lugar de Gambia resulta inseguro. Sino por la crudeza de la vida que allí se expone a la vista, al olfato y a la sensibilidad  del viajero. El mercado es increíble. Hay que visitarlo. No para comprar (que también, si es que quieres comprar gallinas africanas, zapatos usados, cabezas de cordero, polvo de Baobab, o artesanía diversa..). Es un lugar fuera del tiempo, de una fuerza sensorial imposible de encontrar en la "rica" Europa, y de una humanidad tan auténtica, que te hará pensar, y no podrás olvidar.

title: Busy, crowded, hot and scruffy, but worth a visit
text:
This market mixes local and touristy things to purchase, you are hassled a bit, but no where near as bad as Egypt. The title says it all really, but you do need to bargain hard, as they will just try to get as much from you as they can. We always take our friendly taxi driver with us, who gives us an idea of the price to pay, though he does this away from the vendor as they will accuse him of spoiling their business.
A far better and larger market to get a feel of real Gambia is Brikama, this is a proper local market and you will not be hassled at all, though there are few touristy things here, there is a local craft centre nearby.

title: Take a guide
text: Use the local hotel tourist guide for this very busy and narrow market - its fantastic.  Sharpen your bargaining skills,

title: A vibrant colourful market
text: Take a Government Guide (yellow shirts and a badge) and you can look around freely without any hassle.  Fascinating insite into the Banjul way of life.

title: Africa at its best!
text:
Albert Market is in Banjul on Liberation Avenue - a must for every visitor to Gambia. Very busy, very crowded and typycal African. Most parts of the market are just for the local needs and not covering the typical touristic stuff. 
I really enjoyed the atmophere, smell and sounds. However if you are not used to african Markets at least the fish and meat section may be a very different experience.
One of the few must does in Banjul!

title: Suggested Green shopping - and save a life or two!
text:
Why go to a Gambian market and not buy something? Why not buy something and avoid the hassle of carrying it home? Why not buy something that will make an excellent gift and save a life in the process?
I'm suggesting that you visit Banjul market - go by bush taxi (part of the experience) and when you arrive walk along Old Perseverance Street in Albert Market till you come to the shop of Manneh Suwareh, dealer in 'bednets' - mosquito nets, in other words. The nets are well made locally, come in various shades and styles and make superb, life-saving gifts to your favourite hotel staff, village schools, hospitals or casual strangers. Mosquitoes kill people. We take anti-malarials and tend not to visit during the rainy season. Gambian village houses are built to let hot air out, Sadly, this enables mozzies to fly in. Buy a net, give a gift, save a life. Cost? About 200D - the price of a few drinks, and a fraction of the cost you would pay back home.
Manneh is a lovely man; he won't rob you - and you'll probably get a conducted tour of the market thrown in.
